contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=January 2012}} '''Helen Elswyth Thane Ricker Beebe''' (May 16, 1900 – July 31, 1984) was an [[United States|American]] [[romance novel]]ist. Born in [[Burlington, Iowa]], she was the daughter of a local teacher and high school principal." The family moved to [[New York City]] in 1918, and "Helen Ricker" changed her name to "Elswyth Thane". She began working as a freelance writer in the 20s, and became a [[newspaper]] writer and a [[Hollywood]] [[screenwriter]]. Her first novel, ''[[Riders of the Wind]]'', was published in 1926. Her novel, ''[[The Tudor Wench]]'', about [[Elizabeth I of England]], was made into a play. She was a collector of scarves. On September 22, 1927, at 27 years old she married 50-year-old [[natural history|naturalist]] and [[exploration|explorer]] [[William Beebe]]; it was his second marriage.<ref>[http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~dav4is/people/BEEB337.htm "THANE, Elswyth [1900-1984] -- American writer"]</ref> Mrs. [[Theodore Roosevelt]] was one of the guests at the wedding. [[Image:Dr. Beebe in Vermont.jpg|thumb|'Will' Beebe (2nd from left) and wife Elswyth Thane (far right) with friends at home near Wilmington, Vermont in 1957]] Beebe died in 1962, leaving only half of his estate to his widow. She lived on the couple's farm in [[Wilmington, Vermont]]. Her last work, ''[[Fighting Quaker: Nathaniel Greene]]'', was published in 1972. When she died, she left her papers to the [[University of Iowa]]. Thane is most famous for her "[[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]]" series of [[historical fiction]]. The books cover several generations of two families from the [[American Revolutionary War]] up to [[World War II]]. In later books, the action moves from Williamsburg to [[New York City]], [[Richmond, Virginia]] and [[England]].
